III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12405
Section (3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child’s
Description record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency removed foster child from foster home without
paperwork or notification to proper channels.
2

Investigation Reporting Source (RS) was interviewed on 1/10/23 via
telephone. She reported that the agency removed Foster Child A
(FC A) on December 14, 2022, without paperwork or notification to
Foster Parent 1, (FP1). It was reported that the licensing worker
from the agency provided the paperwork the next day regarding
the removal of Foster Child A. The RS said back in November
2022 DHHS investigated a complaint on FP1 and the RS (who
identifies herself as the wife of FP1), due to Foster Child A
reporting she was being spanked. The RS said she and her
children was asked to leave the home until the investigation was
completed and that she was still waiting for someone to contact
her and inform her that she and her children could return back into
the home. It was reported that this has been a month ago and
that now she and her family are running out of houses to move
into. She was concerned as to when she will be able to return
home with her family. It should be noted that the RS stated that
FP1 did not know why Foster Child A was removed, yet RS stated
FP1 was being investigated because there were allegations of the
children in the home being disciplined by spanking. It should also
be noted that at the time of the allegation regarding the spanking
RS was residing in the home, although she was not on the foster
home license and had not been cleared as a caregiver.
The RS then began to make additional allegations against the
agency. The RS reported that she was not in the picture, when
Foster Parent 1, (FP1), was initially licensed. She said they
started dating a year ago in October of 2021. The RS stated she
and her wife never received paperwork on how to add a person to
the license before their marriage.
Chief Administrator and Licensing Director were interviewed
on 1/11/23 and 1/13/23, face to face. The Chief Administrator
reported the following regarding paperwork and notification of the
removal of FC A from FP1:
• 11/28/2022 – The licensing worker followed up with FP1
that the requested documents that was sent to FP1 for RS
needed to be completed and that RS and her children
could not live in the home until everything was completed.
• 11/28/2022 – A first home visit with adoption worker was
completed for FP1 and FC A. The adoption case manager
met with FC A and FC A reported she was getting
spanked.
3

• 11/29/2022 – The agency opened a special investigation
on the home regarding the spanking of FC A. DHHS also
initiated a special investigation.
• 11/30/2022 – During the interviews of FP1’s biological
child, adopted child and FC A at their respective schools,
the agency learned that physical discipline was occurring
in the home.
• 11/30/2022 – A safety plan was immediately developed
that indicated no forms of physical discipline was allowed
in the home and that no household members were allowed
in the home until approved by the agency. FP1 signed the
safety plan.
• 12/1/2022 – The foster care worker provided another
safety plan with further detail regarding notification to the
agency of household members being added immediately in
order to be approved, appropriate discipline methods and
behavior management.
• 12/2/2022 – FC A was taken for a physical examination at
DMC Children’s Hospital. There were no findings of
physical abuse.
• 12/14/22 – The agency and DHHS completed a second
interview with RS’s children, and they reported on going
physical discipline and admitted to living in the home of
FP1. FC A was moved on an emergency basis due to the
interviews of on-going physical discipline and RS living in
the home which violated the safety plan for FP1.
Documentation reviewed:
• Agency policies and procedures – signed by the agency
foster care specialist and FP1 dated 8/15/2022.
• First safety plan – signed by the agency foster care worker
and FP1 dated 11/30/2022. This plan stated the FP will not
allow any individual not approved by the agency in the
home; notify the agency of any changes to the household
and not to use any type of physical discipline.
• Second safety plan – signed by FP1 and the foster care
worker on 12/1/2022. This plan was very detailed
regarding non approved household members, iChat,
behavioral management, and the supervision of FC A.
• DHS 30 – Foster Parent/Caregiver notice of removal for FC
A. The foster care worker signed the report on 12/14/2022
and the DHHS representative and FP 1 signed the report
on 12/15/2022.
The Licensing Director reported that FP1 was notified verbally that
paperwork was being signed to move FC A on an emergency
4

basis due to not following the safety plan and until the special
investigations were completed.
Analysis The agency presented documentation where FP1 was provided
documentation as well as verbal information in regard to the
removal of FC A. There was other governmental agencies
involvement regarding the removal of FC A and her safety. Due to
documentation observed and interviews of staff, this rule is not in
violation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12311
Section (2) The foster parent/agency agreement shall contain all of the
Description following provisions:
(d) That the foster family has been informed of, an agrees to
follow, agency policies and procedures.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The foster parent has not been informed of, and agrees to
follow, agency policies and procedures pertaining to adding a
new household member to a license.
Investigation Chief Administrator and Licensing Director was interviewed on
1/13/2023. She reported that FP1 received and signed all of the
agency policies and procedures. She reported that although FP1
signed the agency policies and procedures, FP1 was not truthful
with the agencies and did not abide by the policies and
procedures set forth for her to follow.
The Chief Administrator reported that Foster Parent 1 (FP1) never
reported to the agency that she was in a relationship and that she
had gotten married. She said when she learned of this
information, her agency took immediate action. Documentation of
the caseworker notes and foster parents’ signature of policies
were reviewed. A time frame of what occurred with the foster
parents indicated the following:
• FP1 had a reevaluation completed of her home dated
9/6/2021 – 9/5/2022.
• Foster Parent agency agreement was signed by FP1 on
8/15/2022. This agreement outlines the responsibilities of
the agency and the foster parent.
5

• Policies and Procedures were signed by FP1 on 8/15/2022
stating she have read and understand the agency policies
and procedures regarding the children place in her care.
• 1/18/2022 – FP1 provided an iChat to the agency for RS.
FP1 was informed that RS was not an approved caregiver
due to criminal history and was listed on central registry.
• 8/15/2022 – A home visit occurred with FP1 home for her
renewal assessment. FP1 reported she is not currently in
a relationship. During this home visit FP1 reviewed and
signed the agency’s household member policy.
• 11/7/22 – FP1 contacted the agency to inquire that if she
ever gets engaged or married, what steps/paperwork
needed to occur prior to doing so. There was no plan
given by FP1. Information was provided to the foster
parent.
• 11/7/2022- Same day, FP1 sent an iChat, identification
card, and expungement letter for RS. It was noted that the
identification address of RS was the same address as
FP1. The licensing worker informed FP1 that RS could not
live in the home until an assessment was completed. FP1
reported that RS did not live in the home but, only uses
FP1 address for mailing purposes. FP1 did not specify her
relationship to RS at that time. It was noted that FP1 was
never truthful with the agency regarding her living
arrangement with other people living in the home.
• Licensing Worker reported that FP1 was able to obtain
iChat forms and additional information due to FP1 was
previously trying to have people cleared for caregivers.
• 11/15/2022 – FP1 contacted the licensing worker to get
update on RS’s clearances.
• 11/16/2022 – RS criminal and central registry clearances
were ran by the agency and RS was approved as a
caregiver. At this time RS provided a letter from DHHS
showing her central registry expungement. The licensing
worker contacted FP1 and informed her that RS will need
to get a medical statement and TB test completed along
with submitting a birth certificate and the form 1326AH if
RS would like to move into the home. Again noted, FP1
did not state that RS was living in the home.
• 11/28/2022 – FP1 provided the licensing worker with a
medical statement and TB test for RS. Medical statement
reported that a mental health follow up would need to be
obtained for RS.
• A home visit occurred, and RS was present only. RS
reported she had been living in the home for the last three
months. The agency discovered that RS had been living in
6

the home with FP1 and RS’s three children. The agency
had not been informed prior of this information.
• 11/30/2022 – FP1 presented a marriage certificate to the
agency for FP1, and RS dated 11/14/2022. Although
home visits were occurring in the home by the agency, the
agency was totally unaware of additional household
members living in the home.
• 12/1/2022 – Agency provided needed information on how
to add new household members. FP1 provided the
agency with medicals and birth certificates of RS’s three
children.
• A home visit was conducted, and it was reported that RS
and her children was no longer living in the home of FP1.
• 12/5/22 - The agency and DHHS interviewed FP1, and she
admitted that she was in a relationship with RS and that
RS was living in her home. She also admitted to not
disclosing the information to the agency.
A review of documentation in MiSACWIS indicated that FP1 was
informed of all documentation required by the agency pertaining to
the agency policy and procedures.
Documentation reviewed:
• Agency policies and procedures – signed by the agency
foster care specialist and FP1 dated 8/15/2022.
• FP1 had a reevaluation completed of her home dated
9/6/2021 – 9/5/2022.
• Foster Parent agency agreement was signed by FP1 on
8/15/2022. This agreement outlines the responsibilities of
the agency and the foster parent.
• Policies and Procedures were signed by FP1 on 8/15/2022
stating she have read and understand the agency policies
and procedures regarding the children place in her care.
Analysis All of the documentation was signed by the foster parent/s
indicating that FP1 was aware, understood and agreed to follow
the agency policies and procedures.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
